@David, you are right. Your Chinese student is not uncommon among many Chinese, especially the educated class. They love Japanese culture. And readers should know Chou En-lai was a student in Japan

So there is a love-hate relationship. Culturally, Japan is also known as the "Eastern Repository" (while the Chinese name for Tibet is "Western Repository." So, people who view the recent incidents in pure monetary term really miss a lot of undercurrents

China is a huge market for Japan as much as Japan is a huge market for China. It is a interdependent world

That said, is it just the bottom line? If Japan has steadfastly refuse to acknowledge the pain and miseries it perpetrated? Decades ago, I met a Chinese-Japanese who emigrated to America. He went to high school in Japan in the late 60s. The textbooks even refused to acknowledge it lost WWII. And how about the reaction to the late Iris Chang's The Rape of Nanking? Granted Ms Chang's scholarship has distractors, but it is a window to these nations' psyche

I teach at a Korean university, and Koreans have similar and well justified resentments of Japan. And they have an almost identical island dispute over the Dokdo islands. Many students get angry about Dokdo and historical issues, but many are interested in Japanese culture - movies and food and the like. Many have traveled to Japan, Korea exports to Japan.

I also happen to have a Chinese student, and she is fascinated by Japanese culture. She speaks 4 languages and is open minded.

There are definitely wounds in China and Korea from Japanese aggression earlier on. But I think the younger generations are moving on.

And anyway, Japan is a huge market for China, and ultimately they care about the bottom line.

First everyone in the reigon sees the U.S. reducing its roll there as it is trying to reduce its roll elsewhere and who in the region will dominate it after that reduction. We have been down this road before. China, Japan and Korea(s) are relatively resource poor. Remember that from Japan's viewpoint WW2 was in large part about insuring it raw materials and Energy supply. The Japanese lost that war, but the basic need for energy and resources controled by Japan lives on today. China threatens those resources in several ways!

First, China covets the same resources as Japan for the same reasons. This is not about small islands, this is about lots of oil and gas around the small islands.

Second, China sees itself as the only truly civilized nation on earth, it matters not at all what we think of that view, however we need to recognize that is how the Chinese see things. Japan is the only country that can chalange China in the reigon. There is history of each invading the other in the past and both invading Korea using it as a proxy in their disputes.

Third, everyone has more or less "played nice" since WW2 because of the U.S., past hates aside and wated for the U.S. to get tired and go home. They all believe that will happen soon because of the weakness and lack of consistency in our Foreign Policy thanks to the "Amateurs" in Washington.

If that happens "the gloves will come off"!

It appears to me that a face-saving compromise is needed here. China no doubt believes that it has lost face due to Japan's purchase of the contested islands, giving rise to the Chinese air defense patrols in the area.

The best role for the United States would seem to me to be one of encouraging both sides to claim victory and stand down. Japan can claim that it owns the islands and that its claim is backed by the U.S. China has demonstrated that it is the dominant regional power whose territorial rights must be respected. Both nations can legitimately proclaim victory. That can be followed by a diplomatic handshake and a return to normalcy.

Although I gave up religion many years ago, I went to Sunday school at a Reform Jewish Temple. We were taught about other religions, and visited their churches, were we hear what they believed and saw their services.

In Scandinavian countries, the same animal is called a reindeer. Heaven knows we don't need Palin murdering Rudolph's heirs. (Oh, and it's the females who keep their antlers this late. They display two additional horizontal lines called stadia lines used in determining elevation. So widely used, special slide rules were sold to help with stadia calculations. Palin's website was using a gun sight to incite against Democrats when Rep Gabrielle Giffords was gunned down. Odd how Palin keeps getting free passes playing to the public ignorance.

Anyway, our inclusive celebration needs several symbols. Glad reindeer are among them. Palin, not so much.

As to the other question, yes it's true that the sons of Moses are barely mentioned in the Torah. Gershon is named in Exodus 2:22, which is the "stranger in a strange land" passage. Eliezer is alluded to in Exodus 4:20 ("he took his wife and his sons") and is named in Exodus 18:4, somewhat confusingly with "for he said, 'My father's God was my helper; he saved me from the sword of Pharaoh.' " The confusing part, of course, is that Eliezer seemed to have been named presciently, but this is the Torah of course.

After that, these sons are heard of no more. We know that parts of the Torah seem to repeat other parts, often with slight differences in the telling. There are many theories as to how the Torah was "redacted," but it's fairly clear that it combines a Mosaic legacy with an Aaronic one, where the latter minimizes the importance of Moses and stresses Aaron and the (then still extant) priests who drew their legitimacy from him. The abrupt disappearance of Moses' sons, like the story of Moses striking the rock, appear to be Aaronic influence, just as Aaron allowing the creation of the Golden Calf is Mosaic.

Historical interpretation of the Torah is a delicate subject, but a fascinating one.

China has traditionally viewed itself as the center of the world, a global ruler that is due respect. This world view has endured for thousands of years and, I believe, characterizes the People's Republic, much as it did the preceding dynasties.

The events of the mid-18th through mid-20th centuries, when Chinese power was at its nadir, indeed engendered bitterness. Even so, the Chinese are masters of the long view and (with notable exceptions such as the Cultural Revolution) typically proceed with admirable discipline on the world stage, with the objective of gradually regaining hegemony.

Here's how much we value doing a difficult, demanding job in the U.S.

When I served in Vietnam for 14 months in 1969 and 1970 I was an E-4 with less than 2 years in the service. Not including combat pay and a few other minor allowances, my pay was $214.20.

An E-4 in 2012 with the same qualifications, not including other pay, was paid $1,946.70.

The pay for putting your life on the line for your nation went up by just over 9 times in 44 years.

1965 to 2012, average CEO compensation of the 350 largest companies increased from $807,000 per year, and $765,000 in options granted, to $14,074,000 a year and $10,735,000.

According to a Huffington Post story, "The head of a typical public company made $9.6 million in 2011" and corporate profits broke records.

Meanwhile average workers struggle and soldiers pay is in question, stalled by Congress and the White House.

Is this a great country?

Or what?

China isn't exactly trying to follow in our footsteps. They are just doing the natural next step in trying to protect their borders after their history of being colonized. They've been trying to avoid policing the world the way the U.S. does, but having economic power has by default created expectations that they will do so. They haven't, yet, and that's not the Chinese mentality from long tradition. Basically, the U.S. is trying the olde Anglo-Saxon tactic of divide-and-conquer by sowing discord between other Asian countries and China, and cozying up to any conflict they get whiff of. It's always easy to find jingoists in any country to exacerbate conflicts where none need to be.

My hope is that China will surprise everyone by being wise and magnanimous by offering other countries some island here or there in return for the ones they want. The problem is, some disputed islands close to their borders are under other control due to old colonial legacies, so they will seem like an aggressive takeover, when in fact historically the islands were previously aggressively taken over by the other party. Meanwhile other islands have key resources that are hard to give up.

I find some of the comments here amusing for their bias and their lack of perspective.  China tries to assert control over a bunch of  tiny Japanese held islands in their own backyard and we call them a big bully. When was the last time we look at ourselves in the mirror?  I don't hear anybody here complained when we toppled foreign governments we don't  like or bombed civilians in the Middle East and Afghanistan in our war on terror. We have troops stationed on almost every continent and naval fleets patrolling every ocean on the globe whereas the Chinese have none. We're in the major league and they're in the little league. So who's the bigger bully now? Talk about self-righteous indignation. Has it ever occurred to some of you that maybe the Chinese are just trying to follow in our footsteps?

Wars don't start because of "accidents spinning out of control". It has never happened. Barbara Tuchman was wrong; the Germans were planning on war at a suitable opportunity, and the Austrians (with help from the Black Hand of Serbia) gave it to them.

Wars start either because one party has decided the the risks of war are preferable to the continuance of the status quo, or because two parties' "red lines" overlap (there is something, such as disputed territory, that both will go to war to hold or obtain).
